reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initially I was unsure about the game. You might be to. The UI is clunky, windows don't stay where you put them, fast travel breaks things, etc etc... welcome to alpha. KEEP GOING ANYWAY. They are making a tremendous effort to voice act the whole game. I found myself actually listening to the quests. I am enjoying a storyline that is becoming increasingly compelling as you not only struggle to rescue stranded colonists but unravel the secrets of this world. It is truely a gem. However in the interest of disclosure I am playing alpha 0.752. So I will list the pros and cons given this version, so that you can decide for yourself if its worth the money.

Cons:
- Alpha bugs (these will go away but player beware them) Fast travel breaks quests and resets window location. In fact theres a long list of bugs, many specific to a persons game. None of them were game breaking for me personally. Very polished for an alpha imho.
-Mining is INCREDIBLY slow. Painfully even if you've ever played minecraft. If you think you are going to change the basic terrain in any meaningful way, you are wrong.
-AI is often baffeling. They apear to be nearsighted and terrified of jumping over obsticals. Often I found them on an impossibly vertical surface stuck in place. Time to break out the pickace and carve em off, slowly though, because the pickaxe does nothing quickly. Or just standing around uselessly while I fire away at giant robots getting cut to ribbons by death lasers because they can't see far enough away to be useful. Same goes for turrets, which more often than not get blown up before even firing. Layerback quest is poorly designed as one of the npcs is not invincible and imediately dies unless you bury him in a hole and cover him over. Alpha is alpha.
-VTOL (Vertical Take Off and Landing) design has basically nothing to do with reality, and a redesign of the controls for making them in general could use a looksee. You can do it, its just not easy to scale parts, and they don't go bigger than their original size... you'll see what I mean. They fly like they're on rails, and really need tuning up to 'feel' more realistic. See: Battlefield 2142 transport.
- Geometry in general. There is no ryhme or reason for running through the base of trees. Accessing the meat from a carcase is an artform not a science. ETC. I'm guessing this is an alpha issue as well but if they don't go back soon and unfrak the situation its going to be a depressing amount of work later for the devs.
-Grass... the amount is as staggering as it is GPU shattering. The sensativity of the levels isn't intelligent. Theres basically several options including: none, Too much, holy good god, 1fps, and the all important personal home computer melter level in case ur tired of your pc. I set it at too much. I advise you to do the same, unless you're running a quantum based supercomputer.

Pros:
-Amzaing story with believable motives, and real characters, which you actually care about because its...
-Voice Acted. Hoorah for immersion. Keep it up. Some bits are misssing here, especially when traveling and they randomly talk. I really hope they continue with this effort because everyone who's ever played another MMO has been in a TL;DR accept, kill, turn in kinda mood. This game slows it down, and makes you care, without pulling teeth. Its glorious.
-Great Characters. Had to add this on its own. Everyone is believable, at least human-side. Very important to stay away from the classically I'm evil

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSteam is being flooded by sandbox exploration games right now. Next to starbound, this is one of my favorite. It still needs more work, but even in its current state, it is a lot of time sucking fun. What sets this game apart from others of its kind is that it is NOT 2D (its Voxel shaded...i don't really know what that means...) and the construction system. You can actually build cars and motorcycles in the game (as well as aircraft, eventually). You don't just collect the resources and then put it together at a crafting table, however...you use the in-game design tools to design how your vehicle will look, down to the paintjob and decals. My first vehicle was a model-T looking car with a huge turret, and 6 wheels to support all its weight. In addition to the construction system, you also have a massive and interesting environment, populated by a whole host of strange animals...like 6 armed fire-breathing bears. The music is also quite relaxing. There's a story-mode which makes it all the more interesting, as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You're trying to seed human life on a new world. As you descend, your ship collides with what looks like some sort of magic hover city, destroying both it and your ship. Small life pods eject, sending those who weren't killed in the first explosion down to the surface to try their damndest to survive.
That's where you begin.

Help your fellow crewmates heal their injuries and collect together, defend against the occasional monster stampede and assemble a fortress to protect those who remain as you struggle to secure life, and begin the existence you intended from the start. Will you make friends with the indingenous sentient species? Can you even survive their outrunners long enough to try? Learn designs to assemble all the things needed to live well and comfortably, from huge laser cannons that rest on top of your most vulerable buildings to eggshell chairs like people loved in the 1970s, you eventually learn it all from your friends and potential new allies.
But there is more danger than you might think at first.
Beware, explorer, the depths of the forests for they hold creatures I can only refer to as like the Chimeras of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. fame. Oceans, fish that could eat blue whales in 5 bites. The skies conceal huge birds, but a quick wit and a well-maintianed rifle can nearly keep you even from being harmed by them.

What will you build? An impenetrable steel fortress with 30 foot walls that stand in mocking defiance of the local beasts? An underground compound filled with laberynthine passages and high-tech facilities? A huge golden tower gleaming in the sun, staring down from a huge mesa or mountainrange?

That's for you to decide.

The only thing the makers of the game care about, is you enjoy their carefully crafted world of make-believe.

At a glance, Planet Explorers feels a lot like another MMO.  This is especially true if you play Adventure mode.  Not being all that into MMOs myself, I was at first a little wary.  Soon enough, however, the lovely scenery, interesting aliens, and a crafting system that has a variety of levels of depth, and I was already humming along and happily harvesting plants.

The crafting system is excellent.  There is a basic level, where you learn scrips" and then build objects out of stuff that is in our inventory.  Then there is a deep level
date: where you can build any 3D object you want and it becomes available in the game.\n\nI also really enjoyed the aliens.  Especially at first
recommended: you never know what an alien is going to do till it sees you.  Then you learn really quick.  The scale of aliens is also great.  There are beings tiny like us meek humans
hoursPlayed: and towering giants that either ignore you
voteText: or quickly put you out of your alleged mysery.\n\nThis game can only go up as it gets more and more polished.  I'm happy to be in somewhere near the ground floor!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never could get into minecraft, but this game seems like it's pretty much the same thing but a whole lot prettier (which was the major turnoff of minecraft for me). It also allows for the creation of custom weapons, vehicles, and buildings as well. My only real gripe is that it doesn't come with any premade vehicles or buildings. This is easily fixed by downloading ISO files made by other players, and as the community grows these downloadable addons will get even more impressive I'm sure.

All in all, it's a pretty addictive little game that gives you nearly complete freedom to make (or download) whatever you want. It runs great, even as an alpha. I've managed to build a rather enormous base complex (six story building, glass dome covering the area, underground tunnels leading to a nearby cliffside, hanger bay and another large stucture embedded in the mountainside..) and the game still runs just fine. So far it's only crashed when I attempt to approach the area at max speed in an aircraft. Approach too quickly and it doesn't load all that fast enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has to be one of the best games i've played in a while, Although the game is in Alpha stage and some patches fix things and some break things, It has alot of potential to go forward and become an outstanding game.

You have a single player mode where you follow the story line and interact with NPC's to perpare yourself for whats to come.
You can build weapons from scratch using the build mode, Providing you have the resources and the same for ground and air transport.

The game offers,
Single player story line, Mining, resource gathering, mob hunting, base building, designing anything from sword to pistols to 4 barrel guns, how ever you want to design them, the more damage the weapon the better.
You can also build Cars, helicopters and so on. Disign it how you want it to look. It also has crafting of items that you will need in the game, from spades to mining tools, lights, food and much more.

The game also has Multiplayer, which includes all the above with either Co-op or PvP.
Work as a team to build a base and defend it from the many mobs in the game or fight your fellow players in PvP destroying there base and taking it to the wire.

It has a great community who are willing to help those who need the help and the game has so much more to add.
With patches and improvements adding to the game to improve it, and much more to come.

I recommend anyone who understands Alpha phase games to join in and get on board to make this the best open world RPG out there, you will have alot of fun. If you like Minecraft and those types of games.

There are bugs as there are with many Alpha games, but this is more polished then most i've played of late. Including some currently on steam.

A review yes, because I want all my friends to enjoy and play this!

The game has now seen many huge updates and was already a healthy playable game from day one. It has been fun seeing what they are contantly adding because they have listened to the players on this point too.
I find myself longing back to this magical experience and will re-start it from the begining as so many changes have been made.
You only have to check out any of the developers videos or reviews to understand. I have always wanted a huge alien world to explore with a complete survival experience and thats what you get.

This is a wonderful voxel world dripping in atmousphere, were you decide what and were you build your base or camp; inside a huge rock, then digg tunnels maybe wide enough to drive that hoverbike you just designed straight in or maybe a huge base out over the sea?!
Want to build a flying craft, you can, want to farm or just trade, you can!
They have since added a scanning tool which enables you to see whats under ground; were a type mineral might be and also were there might be a cave.

It fast become my fav game of all time last year and has only become better; were you just feels so good being in this beautifully colored world with tough creatures to hunt and riches to digg for.

I could go on and on, yet would only amount to spoilers for the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best Early Access games I've played to date. There is a lot of content here.

Offline the single player has a storyline where you take quests and learn the ins and outs of crafting. There is also an Adventure Mode where the world is procedurally generated and you have to explore and survive with only a handful of NPC villagers.

Online works as well. You can play on a server for adventure, versus or just building with unlimited resources.

You can also create your own buildings in build mode as well as create custom vehicles and weaponry with their in game creation system. It's quite robust, albeit a bit clunky at first.

The game still has a way to go, with some UI and camera issues to iron out as well as more character customization options. Like I said, it's one of the best Early Access games you can play now and with content and updates coming regularly it's must have for anyone who enjoys adventure with mixed with crafting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Scroll Down For older review from March 15 2014.

I recently replayed Planet explorers early this year, I was kind of worried about the new changes seeing as in my mind the development for the a0.9 build is going at a snails pace, as expected with a overhaul update however even though I cannot add anything new to the earlier review I made in March 15 2014 I have to retract my statement on underpowered custom weapons, it took me a few hours of just watching other players to realize that the aesthetics of a weapon also effect it's stats... To the people who were swayed away from this game for that earlier statement I must say I am sorry for my Ignorance.

Secondly, when I was saying the monsters are overwhelming in my review I was meaning for extremely early game players or people who, at the time, like me, did not know how the custom weapons worked, after about 30 minutes of playing most mobs will be a cake walk to kill if you spent your time in the editor for rifles.


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When I first got this I expected it to be alot like minecraft just with (proper) RPG elements thrown in. What I got was a game that I can say I truly enjoy. [Pros and Cons listed below]

Pros-

Outstanding music

Engaging storyline

Constant updates

Ok-great graphics

Diverse mobs and flora

Colony System

massive world

Npc Party System
--------------------------------
Now for the bad parts.
-------------------------------
Cons-

Construction can be confusing at times

The creation system is only good for shields and vehicles (underpowered custom weapons)

The feeling of being overwhelmed at times by the sheer number of activities

Voxel based construction makes tunnels a nuisance to build
-----------------------------------------
Time for the barely noticeable bits.
-----------------------------------------

Ill noticed Cons-

Drunk walking (from time to time the character decides to not walk in a straight line)

Anchored Vehicles (the vehicles tend to slam themselves into the ground when moving over terrain) [Choppers not effected]

Suicidal Vehicles [Caused By Anchored Vehicles] (vehicles like to damage themselves if not properly suspended from the ground in the creator)

Npcs go brain dead from time to time.


Ill noticed Pros-

Hillarious glitches (In my mind thats a pro)
--------------------------------------------------
Cons for minecraft fan boys and girls-

It takes a while to get resources, this is a game of patience not one that the creators expect you to speed run.

Overwhelming enemies, the creators of this game really want you to show caution when playing.

--------------------------------------------------
Final Judgemenet
--------------------------------------------------

In the end I'd give this game a 8/10      [NOTE: Review is subject to change as the game progresses through its updates]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a good game for people interested in a minecraft type of experience. Those looking for a PVP or Hardcore RPG experience will be disappointed. At this point, the game is very limited but don't take this to mean that you can't do anything. The framework is here for a super awesome exploration/building/crafting game. It has an autocad type editor that you can spend hours recreating cars, planes, guns, swords, or decorative items from films, television, and other games. My buddy and I downloaded someone's jurassic park jeep creation and rode around among the giant creatures. It was very cool.

Summary
Active Developers with frequent updates
Single player campaign
Open world exploration with NPC quest givers
Mining and Crafting
Randomly seeded world for multiplayer with co-op
MANY, MANY BUGS
SLOW Game Play
Difficult multiplayer hosting and connection process
Multiplayer works off and on

If you're looking at Planet Explorers wait a little bit before buying the game unless you find it on sale. Development is slow going but consistent. I DO NOT feel cheated by the developer at all. I recommend this game for those interested in it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is a very unique game. While it does come with several short-comings which I will discuss later, the game itself is very well rounded and based on a sound survival tactical idealism that is reminiscient of minecraft, but has dutifully ascended to what Minecraft could never quite achieve; and it's still not complete!

Before I dive into what I truly love about Planet Explorers, it would only be fair if I start with a few of it's shortcomings. The first thing is the fact that early game survivability is ridiculously odd, with a botchy combat system and not quite complete progression, this game lacks any motivation to keep on playing past the bad in hopes of reaching something good. Not to mention how ridiculously easy it is to aquire the best gear in the game through the incomplete store function. Sure, while the ability to design your own vehicles and weapons is cool, it's not really something to be all that impressed about, it's very linear about voxel placement and the damage to size ratio is far off to say the least.

But putting all of that on the back burner, I would like to now dive in to what I thought was amazing about the game, and the reasons that I kept playing through the faults. The in-game world is beautifully designed, and provides motivation to explore and just admire the scenery. The colony function allows you to find people out in the wildnerness who you can ask to join you and before you know it, you can get a whole group of people following you around. The combat system is great, but part of the problem with it is just how poorly animated it is, but that's very easy to put aside. The animals and aliens in this game are not only well designed, but also are varied in appearance and combat strategy, it will make it difficult to say raid an alien colony without preparation, and it makes your troubles worth it in the end. With a good story mode and great functionality for a game that's still unfinished, it's hard to point out that many faults in it. And even then, to find anything really wrong with the game I had to nitpick.

If I was going to rate this game, I'd have to give it at least a 7/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Of all the sandbox early access games on Steam, this seems so far the most promising. And indeed, the most complete ~ *cough* DayZ *cough*

I was entirely taken aback by the MMORPG-like feel from the get go, and it initially made me weary. It took exactly five minutes to forget any of that, thanks to the addictive harvesting, mining, building and just generally extremely well-done crafting in this game. This game so far has *the* best customization that I have seen, and knocks Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri and Galactic Civilizations 2 down from their previously shared throne in this aspect IMO.

The parallells to Minecraft are also subdued - thankfully.

Apart from The Secret World, I don't think I've ever been more immersed in an over-the-shoulder perspective game. Sure, the music is mostly licenseware, the voice acting sounds like a school class project, and some textures are extremely flat; but I find myself ignoring a lot of what would otherwise be real annoyances for me because of the overall charm this game has.

Probably the main strength this game has is the authentic-feeling world. Multiplayer has some procedural niggles that I hope will be gone after alpha, but the single player (and selectable in multiplayer) canon" world quite possibly is the most authentic
date: immersive "alien looking" world I've seen since The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. And to be sure
recommended: Planet Explorer's flora and fauna has a lot in common with Morrowind
hoursPlayed: to the point that it feels like an homage

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this is still an incomplete game, it's very, very nice. Yes, it's an indy game: it doesn't have some of the extreme polish you get in the big company's titles. But it's fun.
I'm playing in story mode at the moment, which gives me some building, some adventure, and (you guessed it), the story.

Its incompleteness is showing in a few places. For me, the most annoying is with the scanner: it doesn't give a clear indication of where the character is in relation to the minerals you're scanning; nor does it give a clear indication of your facing.
I also would prefer a gamma or brightness control (either!) in the video settings.

That said, I'm thoroughly enjoying the game. For fans of story-driven games, open world adventure gaming, or colonisation/city building, this is definitely worth a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE:  Review will change if they fix things.  However, I'm writing this review because things have been too rough and unfinished for too long.  Especially the game breaking bug for if you have anything plugged in other than keyboard + mouse.

------------------------------

Extremely, *extremely* buggy, even for an early access title.

If you have any controller plugged in, or use vJoy or any head tracking, you have to disable them from the device manager before you load up the game.  There are no options to disable controllers or joysitcks ingame at this time.

If you don't disable your peripherals, the camera will bug out and spin around your characters feet, making the game unplayable.

If you DO disable them and try to generate a world to play in, the world is very buggy.  Your character can run through objects in the starting village, and can run up and down sheer cliffs.

It doesn't feel like a sandbox game like Minecraft or Kerbal Space Program.  It feels like a very, very shoddy MMORPG that you play on your own.  Especially the combat system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What to say about Planet Explorers?
Well, I play it since March /14 (almost in its release date, few days later).
I watched some videos, seen some screnshots, and why not, right?

Some indie games have a tendency of not completing its development to full release, because of a lot of reasons, but what the hell? I tried and bought it anyway.

Of course I do not have a lot of hours, playing since 2014, because I tend to stop playing and watch the development, by the Devs or Youtubers, so I can have more accurate opinion about it and it give me the way to play.

So, speaking about the game itself: It is a sandbox, indie, open world, survival crafting adventure (that I love most). I may be exagerating if I say that this is a better Minecraft, but this is my opinion, so yeah.

You can craft components, weapons, furniture and ETC, and can build your home / base / castle / whatever. Did I mention that you can CREATE your own weapons? you can use their Voxel Tool to create the most beautiful and weird weapons and shields (weapons: sword, guns), but this doesn't stop there. You actually can create your own vehicle by the same voxel system. You have a limited box of creation, but this does not mean your creations will be limited. You can create small and large ground carriers, you can create aircraft and boats. The adventures with your own creations are so awesome!

I must admit that the game have a lot missing, and I don't need to explain what is it, because, the game grow in every update released.

Some may think about the update time, that it takes too long to hit Steam. I must agree on some of that, but cannot stop thinking that they are still working. I say that because I tought, long time ago (end 2014 / beginning 2015) that they gave up developing the game, because of the great delays of updates. I had uninstalled the game a lot of times, because of lack of hope, but then, I redownloaded it and played again, with new features that I didn't see it coming.

Now I know one thing: they release updates, not too frequent, but when it hit Steam, the updates always come with very good improvements, and I mention bug fixes to new features.

So, pleople, don't be afeared of Planet Explorers. They are working, and the game looks beautiful.

I have invested in the game and it is showing its potential so far.

Obs: If my words seem a little weird, I am not a native of the language, so I apologize, and no, I have nothing to do with Pathea Games.

Thank you and support them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first bought and played Planet Explorers over 2 years ago, I loved it and couldn't wait to see how it evolved.
All this time later and the A09 update they have talked baout for so long finally happens, so I give it another 3 weeks and several updates to make sure things are ironed out okay before going back.

Its terrible. Single player is worse than it was 2 years ago in some way and only marginally better in other ways, and trying to play any mode with a friend is still the buggy waste of time it was 2 years ago.
The newly added co-op story mode I was excited to finally play with a friend was too broken to play too.

At this point, there are simply lots of better games to choose from that are actually going somehwere. Planet explorers has taken FAR too long to do far too little, and at this point it shouldnt cost what it does anymore.
Its a real shame, but I don't see this game ever being done. if it ever is though, it won't even matter anymore.
Too little too late.

Its a shame the game still has the misleading mostly positive reviews just because of the great reception it got years ago. Most of those should be negative now but I believe those players that had hope then gave up long ago and never even came back to say so.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is one of a number of surivival games I have in my library, and like most the game is in early access so I find it hard to review it as I know the game is in constant flux.  That being said after a few hours of playing I have to say that Planet Explorers is one of those games that I feel let down with.   I followed from Kickstarter forward and had high hopes for this sandbox.  This has a lot of promiss and isn't a bad game per say.  This is one of those games that I really wish that there were a sliding scale instead of just a yes/no for recommending because I hate saying I don't recommend because unlike TUG I think the game really tries, but the problem is that I think it tries to do too much in some ways.   I think that while it has potential to be a better game in the end than GRAV right now GRAV beats it out.   I have to compare it to GRAV as to me that is the closest match as far as feel.   I will come back in a few months and review however I feel that I have enough time in the game to review and wanted to do so.   So while I am at this time not recommending I am doing so saying that while I am marking as No that I am rating as a 6/10 which is to say that the game is better than it is bad, however if your money is tight you might want to hold off.  However if you are a game collector like me and don't mind picking up EA games and being patient and willing to take a gamble I think maybe in a year or 18 months the game may change my mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this is early access and so I will treat it as such in my review.

Right now I cannot recommend this to all but the most die hard EA players that must try everything before they are released.  I'll be brief as I can.  There are some positives about this game but in a nutshell it's not ready yet for me to give it a full thumbs up.  Wish Steam had a way to give 1 to 5 stars.  If this were a star rating I'd give it a 3 for now.

It seems like it has a lot of potential.  The graphics, while a bit simple, are attractive enough, in a cute, and cartoony way.  If that look is something that appeals to you it will fit in just fine.  I don't mind that aspect but just pointing that out.  Which brings me to the first downside.  with the simplified graphics, i don't understand with a very capable gaming computer like I have, why it has stutter, quite frequently.  I would say every 20 to 30 seconds the game stutters for a moment and although it's not game breaking it is quite annoying.

The positives from my prior game plays (where I played quite a bit more time back weeks ago) I like:  the gathering, build mode and craft-heaviness of the game at least early on.

The combat could use some polish along with the gathering aspects.

The tutorial or beginning doesn't tell you much about how to do things and although I don't want hand holding for every little thing, it would be nice for the basics like how to open the replicator.  Basics like this, I know you can find in help but I will venture to guess that most players don't like to spend their early minutes in a game looking up how to do all the basic stuff.

Again, this game could be good once all details are worked out, and I will keep an eye out but for now I cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First time doing a serious review of a game, so please bear with me.

NOTE: This review is for version A0.82 so my opinion may change for better or worse over time.

With that all over with, let's get to the review.

Prologue and Creation/building system 9/10
Planet explorers is a voxel based open world building/RPG game with Singleplayer/multiplayer support. The game is very playable for an alpha game, and deserves all the credit possible for that feat alone. It's one of the best games I've played this year, and has lots of replay value through the creation system on its own. The building system in this game is one of its strong points. It improves upon something that games like Minecraft fall short on. It gives you the ability to enter a free cam mode and build as you see fit, with support for curved edges, slopes, ramps, and everything else of the sort. The creation system is fun to use, but really flimsy with its actual usage ingame. So far I've seen little use for ground vehicles, aside from being cool looking sometimes. The weapons are terribly weak and could be improved upon. When my 1000 meat pistol does more damage than 20,000 meat tank, then you have a problem. But all that aside, I've spent a majority of my time on this game making vehicles and weapons. It truly gives the power to the players. With admins stating that they plan to add extensive mod support for this game in later builds, I see it having a very long and prosperous life. Instant classic.

Combat 5/10
The combat system in Planet Explorers is very clumsy to say the least. You lunge forward with melee weapons and flail around like an idiot hoping you hit something, while the massively overpowered giant monsters make scraps of you. I've used 3+ revival shots on fights that should'nt even need healing. The ranged weapons are bearable, but the Ocarina of Time camera angle it throws you into makes moving and shooting very annoying. In the end I found myself relying on grenades and placing down my Artillary cannons to deal with monsters instead of actually fighting them.

Exploration 5/10
The game is not very rewarding for its exploration, with all of the ore veins being deep underground and very scattered, there's no reason to use your scanner unless you know exactly where the veins are. I havn't played adventure mode much to know about how bad the ore veins are in there, but the ore veins in story are massive and widely spread apart. Its taken my 10+ minutes just to get a petrol vein I needed, and another 20+ minutes to try and make sense of how to dig to it.

Mining 7/10 (4/10 without guides.)
This is the only game where I've only wanted to get 20 copper out of a vein, but came out with 3000. For some reason the mining in this game is awefully enrapturing. But my poiny from before remains clear, the process of getting to the ore is very agonizing, to say the least. Especially when you're not relying on guides to find the ores. Before I knew they were in set locations, I spent an hour or two on finding a silver deposit.

Vehicles 8/10
Vehicles are fun, but clumsy. Ground vehicles are like moving bricks, and take damage from everything. Their weapons are extremelly lacking, and eat through what little power they have like nothing. Aircraft are similar with power problems, but by the point you get Aircraft in the story mode you have a means to refuel them. Aircrafts also have much more versatile weapon systems. I cannot give opinions on boats, I've never used them or needed to use them. Sorry.

Overall Alpha score: 7/10
Presumed Release score: 9/10
Personal scoring: 8/10 (Meaning how much I enjoy the game as a whole, not just getting an average.)

If you came to this game from Minecraft, you are in the wrong place, this game requires a lot more time and effort to get to a reasonable standing, but is much more rewarding.

Sorry if my reviewing skills are undesirable, I just felt the need to review one of my favorite games to date.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Short Summary
If you like open world sanbox games, freedom to build whatever you want and a really pretty looking environment to do it in that is filled with really cool creatures buy this game!

The Pros
-Amazing object/vehicle creation (see below)
-Huge, pretty world
-Promising storyline
-Stable (I haven't had a single crash)
-Nice soundtrack

The Cons
-Some sounds/voices missing
-Occasional bugs
-Occasional graphical glitches
-Not all of storyline is finished yet
-Fairly steep learning curve (no tutorial yet)

My Review
I had my eye on this game for ages but was undecided - quite often Early Access games can end up being a waste of time and money.  I had previously tried an early alpha demo (available for free from their website but does not do the game justice at all) and was put off by the fact that it seemingly required a click to move the mouse.  Little did I know that pressing F2 enables shooter mode" and allows the camera to follow the mouse.  Epic.  From the moment I figured that out I was snared.
It is fun to play
recommended: pretty and basically everything you want in an open-world RPG sandbox game!\n\nOne of the biggest selling points is the editor/creator interface - where most games will allow you to make a simple "custom" vehicle out of snap-together parts
hoursPlayed: this actually allows you to use both simple and complex shapes combined with prefab parts to create vehicles in any shape that you like!  When you have finished designing a vehicle you save it and it gets stored in your in-game library and can be used in any game mode. The story mode led me from hub to hub, but I'm still only scratching the surface of this because I was distracted by a looming mountain; I wonder if I can dig a tunnel through that mountain" *2 hours later* "yeah!". There is a progression in what schematics you have available

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First time doing a serious review of a game, so please bear with me.

NOTE: This review is for version A0.82 so my opinion may change for better or worse over time.

With that all over with, let's get to the review.

Prologue and Creation/building system 9/10
Planet explorers is a voxel based open world building/RPG game with Singleplayer/multiplayer support. The game is very playable for an alpha game, and deserves all the credit possible for that feat alone. It's one of the best games I've played this year, and has lots of replay value through the creation system on its own. The building system in this game is one of its strong points. It improves upon something that games like Minecraft fall short on. It gives you the ability to enter a free cam mode and build as you see fit, with support for curved edges, slopes, ramps, and everything else of the sort. The creation system is fun to use, but really flimsy with its actual usage ingame. So far I've seen little use for ground vehicles, aside from being cool looking sometimes. The weapons are terribly weak and could be improved upon. When my 1000 meat pistol does more damage than 20,000 meat tank, then you have a problem. But all that aside, I've spent a majority of my time on this game making vehicles and weapons. It truly gives the power to the players. With admins stating that they plan to add extensive mod support for this game in later builds, I see it having a very long and prosperous life. Instant classic.

Combat 5/10
The combat system in Planet Explorers is very clumsy to say the least. You lunge forward with melee weapons and flail around like an idiot hoping you hit something, while the massively overpowered giant monsters make scraps of you. I've used 3+ revival shots on fights that should'nt even need healing. The ranged weapons are bearable, but the Ocarina of Time camera angle it throws you into makes moving and shooting very annoying. In the end I found myself relying on grenades and placing down my Artillary cannons to deal with monsters instead of actually fighting them.

Exploration 5/10
The game is not very rewarding for its exploration, with all of the ore veins being deep underground and very scattered, there's no reason to use your scanner unless you know exactly where the veins are. I havn't played adventure mode much to know about how bad the ore veins are in there, but the ore veins in story are massive and widely spread apart. Its taken my 10+ minutes just to get a petrol vein I needed, and another 20+ minutes to try and make sense of how to dig to it.

Mining 7/10 (4/10 without guides.)
This is the only game where I've only wanted to get 20 copper out of a vein, but came out with 3000. For some reason the mining in this game is awefully enrapturing. But my poiny from before remains clear, the process of getting to the ore is very agonizing, to say the least. Especially when you're not relying on guides to find the ores. Before I knew they were in set locations, I spent an hour or two on finding a silver deposit.

Vehicles 8/10
Vehicles are fun, but clumsy. Ground vehicles are like moving bricks, and take damage from everything. Their weapons are extremelly lacking, and eat through what little power they have like nothing. Aircraft are similar with power problems, but by the point you get Aircraft in the story mode you have a means to refuel them. Aircrafts also have much more versatile weapon systems. I cannot give opinions on boats, I've never used them or needed to use them. Sorry.

Overall Alpha score: 7/10
Presumed Release score: 9/10
Personal scoring: 8/10 (Meaning how much I enjoy the game as a whole, not just getting an average.)

If you came to this game from Minecraft, you are in the wrong place, this game requires a lot more time and effort to get to a reasonable standing, but is much more rewarding.

Sorry if my reviewing skills are undesirable, I just felt the need to review one of my favorite games to date.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing, even more so when you remember that's it's an alpha.
Graphics are pretty good, I like the style. The music fits in perfectly. The best thing about it would be it's casualness for me. What I mean is, thanks to huge inventory and and very friendly interface, very slowly  breaking tools and no weight restrictions, it feels like a game and not like a chore (cough cough Rust, cough cough Minecraft). I normally don't play this type of games, but Planet Explorers is a damn fine one.
As for story, it's nothing exceptional but it does it's job. Group of people crash on a planet they know next to nothing about and, as humanity always does, start to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and killing anymals, mining ores, cutting trees and harming local ecology in any way they can. Most people give you a little quest, the quests are same as always (fetch something, kill something, craft something etc..) but it works pretty well.
It's absolutely amazing how little bugs there are in this Alpha version.
All and all, great game, don't miss out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Has something special about it. The art is unique and beautiful, the gameplay is so fun and different every playthrough, which is what I personally love. It's not a perfect game at this stage, but it has the potential to be, and most probably will be in the months/years to come.

I can't name all the games, but let's just say this is all your favourite sandbox - open world - survival - builder - simulation games combined into one, with the ability to create anything you like.

- Want a custom Gun? You can make it, shape the body how you want.
- Need you very own version of the Buster sword, but bigger and badder... maybe in Gold? Sure why not.
- Want to create your own Ferrari in the game? Sure you can... it'll take time and patience but the results would be worth it... - How about making your own Houses, with it's own furniture... yeah you guess it, you can make it.

Most things like vehicles needs to have some precreated objects (like the engine of a bike) but its up to you to decide where to place the chairs then model and colour the body however you want. Swords require a Hilt object, guns require the handle and trigger object. But the overall shape of it is down to you.
Everything else, like furniture or houses... you create them how you want.

You will not be disappointed, it's early access and still has plenty of ways to go which only means that the final product will be bigger, badder and awesomer* (if there was ever such a word)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA unique game that really allows you to express yourself, unlike some other 'crafting' games that promised to deliver, but delivered nothing BUT promises. Other then allowing you to create weapons, vehicles, shields and constructs voxel by voxel, this game looks very unique and the design is astounding, from creatures to environments, this game is absoulutely an eye treat and also a fun experience (and probably better with friends). I see a good future for this game, support it.

Explore, Gather, Design, And Survive, Or even go into battle in a PvP mode where only the best team will conquer. 5/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Short Summary
If you like open world sanbox games, freedom to build whatever you want and a really pretty looking environment to do it in that is filled with really cool creatures buy this game!

The Pros
-Amazing object/vehicle creation (see below)
-Huge, pretty world
-Promising storyline
-Stable (I haven't had a single crash)
-Nice soundtrack

The Cons
-Some sounds/voices missing
-Occasional bugs
-Occasional graphical glitches
-Not all of storyline is finished yet
-Fairly steep learning curve (no tutorial yet)

My Review
I had my eye on this game for ages but was undecided - quite often Early Access games can end up being a waste of time and money.  I had previously tried an early alpha demo (available for free from their website but does not do the game justice at all) and was put off by the fact that it seemingly required a click to move the mouse.  Little did I know that pressing F2 enables shooter mode" and allows the camera to follow the mouse.  Epic.  From the moment I figured that out I was snared.
It is fun to play
recommended: pretty and basically everything you want in an open-world RPG sandbox game!\n\nOne of the biggest selling points is the editor/creator interface - where most games will allow you to make a simple "custom" vehicle out of snap-together parts
hoursPlayed: this actually allows you to use both simple and complex shapes combined with prefab parts to create vehicles in any shape that you like!  When you have finished designing a vehicle you save it and it gets stored in your in-game library and can be used in any game mode.  You can also share yours and download other people's if you fancy!\n\nFor me this game was the final nail in minecraft's little square coffin.  For me it was the fabled minecraft killer!  It doesn't have a huge amount in common but the things that it does (admittedly mainly mining...) are done so much better!  Smooth
voteText: voxel-based terrain makes for a much more fun digging experience and allows you to be much more creative while building defences and tunnels etc.\n\nLong story short
helpfulPercent: I cannot fault this game in any major way - but I cannot stress this enough
votesHelpful: you still have to remember that it is an alpha version!  Although
votesTotal: honestly
votesFunny:
I've paid more for mainstream games that felt less finished and polished than this one in it's current state. :)

So far of the Early Access and Alpha games I've tried out this is one of the only two that I can honestly say has impressed me to this level.  For me it draws level both in creativity and content to Space Engineers - and that is a serious compliment from me considering that I have clocked up over 230 hours into that came.  It is also clear that the developers really want to create a finished product - they usually release fixes not long after new alpha patches come out and also give a rough idea of what is to be expected in the next release.

There are obviously bugs
commentsCount: and certain things could be a little more well explained but honestly this game is worth the tiny amount of time it takes to master the basics!  Features get fixed and new stuff gets added with each update.\n\nSo enough of this review... I'm off to play Planet Explorers!! ;)"

- Probably a ton of other features

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYesterday i came back to this game after a year or so away, and found it seemingly unplayable compared to older versions. I posted a bad review urging people to stay away from it until the devs fix the issues i was having (unresponsive keys/mouse) then something happened about 15 minutes after i posted that makes me change my recommendation to thumbs up. I got a message on steam from one of the devs (very quick response time) who told me how to solve the issues i was experiencing... very easy fix... reset key bindings to default ! I had never thought to do that as i have never changed keybindings on the game, but low and behold, instant fix. I have over 100 hours on this game and was / is among my favorites. Keep up the good work on this game and I want to thank developer zede05 for the quick response and help to make this one of my favorite games once again. VERY much recommended.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet Explorers is nowhere near complete, it is after all, an Alpha. With that consideration in mind, this has the potential to be an amazing game. The only problems I've noticed are that the grass and shadow textures cause all sorts of lag problems, but this can be easily fixed by turning those textures off. The other being how user friendly it is. It is really not very user friendly. There is no real tutorial, figuring out how to get stuff into the game that you made in creation mode can take awhile, and the combat system is a little odd. Keeping in mind that this is in alpha, and it is nowhere near done, I'd say that most of these problems can be fixed, and I am sure they will be even better than I could imagine in time. This game is kinda like minecraft in space, so that's pretty awesome. I also love that there is character interaction, and that the interaction will only get better. Overall, I would reccommend this game strongly. It isn't great yet, but I know it will be.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a beautiful version of minecraft that allows you to explore amazing landscapes.  The controls are fine albeit a bit awkward at times.  Keep in mind this is an Alpha although every game these days seems to be called an Alpha or Beta.  The building capabilities are right down to the nuts and bolts so better reserved for engineers then casual gamers.  For the hardcore player or someone that likes to explore this is cool in Alpha form.  For the casual gamers maybe wait for a later beta or finished product or you'll find yourself stuck for hours trying to build a flintstones car just to progress the storyline.  I dread the day I have to build things that fly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely a good game.  It has held my attention for the most part.  As it stands right now there's obvious issues as it's an alpha.  The current issues I've ran into so far are as follows:

The AI has some pretty bad pathfinding.  They can get stuck on something as small as a mound of dirt.  Which makes you have to keep an eye on them during escort missions where you've ran for 10-15 mins only to realize when you get to your destination that the person you're escorting got stuck half way back.  You're able to have two companions where if they get too far behind they'll teleport next to you.  This needs to happen to escorted NPCs as well.

There's many different ways to travel, however I've only made a car.  While fun and all, they damage very easily.  This may be because it's a starting car I made but the damage accumulated way too fast.  I was only able to drive for 2 mins tops in the forest area before the car blew up.  Every small mound I went over made the car take damage.  Also I found that the cars handling needs a fair amount of tweaking.

I've only just got past the kill the layerback (whetever they're called) mission.  That's where I hit my first roadblock as the quest was either unintentionally unfair or bugged as you're supposed to escort 2 survivors  to kill the layerbacks.  The one guard NPC always rushes in to melee them only to die and fail the mission.  I must have tried the mission literally 30 times, before I just built a wall around him out of harms way and only then could I finish the mission.  They need to certainly fix that as it's more than just a minor annoyance.

All in all this game has certain potential to be really good.  If you can deal with it's quirks as alpha goes along, there's definitely a lot of fun to be had.  Also the fact that you can build you're own cars, vtols and weapons with pre made parts then add voxels to add your own touch to it is really cool.

While I don't think in it's alpha state the price is justified, it will be worth it at full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing even in alpha stage. I never had so much thrills thinking of how much
potential this game has. It's a voxel based game which means the graphics will never be quite good
but having amazing futures no other sandbox, that i know about, has yet makes up for that. For example an in
game 3D modeling tool. Takes a moment to learn but hit me it's amazing.

You can pretty much build anything you like. And with a click of button you have it inside your game. Be it a
railroad, spaceship, castle, weapon, car, shield. You will be able to create pretty much anything. The game automatically
calculates the amount of materials needed to build your creation in game. Giving you a pretty much instant access to a game
where you can make your own game in. Limited by the engine of course.

The futures it has so early in development makes me glad i bought early access. The devs behind
this needs all the cash they can get so they can make one of the most creative sandbox game today.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm impressed. This indie game has accomplished far more and to a much better degree than alot of AAA titles I've played. I suggest picking it up and here's why:

The AI pathfinding is wonderful. A follower only got stuck once and that's because I was trying to build the bridge as we were walking over it and I accidently built ontop of him. So chalk that up to my fault.

Speaking of building I must say this is one of the nicest system I've seen. My only complaint is that I can't make slopes at any angle that I want, but I haven't fully examined the builder so I could've just missed it.

The voxel system creates one of the best mining systems that smoothly change the terrain as you dig and mine for minerals.

The item/vehicle creation is very nice and adds your own touch to the game.

HOWEVER there are some negative point, but these might be solved as time goes on:

The ranged weapons feel inaccurate. Yes you point and shoot and it hits the target, but the pistols feel like the rifles and it all seems the same.

Some claim that the melee combat is like Monster Hunter, but I disagree. You can't specifically mess up a monster's leg or wings. On top of that I haven't found a way to dodge yet so it's been a contest of who can hit harder.

There's no way to sort through the crafting menu. it's alphabetical, but if you forget that what you want is the portible medkit" and not the "small medkit"(which I don't think there is one) then you can make the mistake of thinking you can't craft any small healing items

Despite these complaints I like this game as is and the proposed additions can hopefully only make it better.

EDIT: Upon review in the upper center of the replicator menu there is a way to sort out scripts. I found that it isn't a user friendly as other sorting systems
date: butit does exist and makes things simpler to a degree. Thank you to Thariorn for pointing this out to me."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some people when seeing this game will immeditely think Yay... another Minecraft clone... again!" and would be partly right since this game offers a lot more.
First : the story mode
date: which could potentially be considered a big tutorial for the adventure part
recommended: is actually worth doing if you are (like myself) an amateur of the "stranded adventures" type
hoursPlayed: in many occasions I almost expected Captain Janeway beam down and give me a new assignment.\nSecond : the customization possibilities go way beyond what Minecraft can do (coming from the madman who made the casle of Akashi on minecraft-europe server mostly by himself)
voteText: both in terms of objects AND in vehicules with some really impresive designs you can import in the game just with a drag and drop in the right folder
helpfulPercent: even while the game is till running.\nThird : the environments are gorgeous ! I was a bit scared to end up in pretty barren lands like you could see in Anarchy Online but through the visual style (which reminds a lot of Consortium and/or Star Wars - The Old Republic)
votesHelpful: props and mobs runing around you already have
votesTotal: despite the game being in alpha
votesFunny:
the impression of being in a living world. It really is a joy to see a pack of wolf like creature attacking a herbivore in the middle of a forest. Some may argue that the graphics are not "Next-Gen" but as Yathzee Croshaw would say "Golden pixels are detrimental to the quality of all other aspects of the game" yet even though the game is definitely not the absolute best looking you can tell the guys put some serious work in making the environments colourful and interesting to travel in (I had to pick up my jaw on the floor a few times in fact).

On the less good parts :
- The game currently has some issues with quest in story mode blocking (a character giving a quest that pops up and dissappear right away or conditions not validating being the most common issues)
commentsCount: some people apparently didn't had much problems but I'm currently stuck after 12 hours of questing. Probably somethings patching will correct so I don't mind that much.\n- You can shape the land as you see fit in theory only because it is actually quite difficult to accurately mine things
column16: for example trying to mine a perfectly straight tunnel at an angle can become a nightmare really fast because the character is always sliding on slopes
column17: which brings to the next point.\n- Controls are a bit cluncky with a big hindrance of the camera not always placing itself in the best angle for the action and the vehicules being a bit difficult to accurately tune in regards to the power/weight ratio and turning angle
column18: meaning a vehicule can have a tendency to do a 180° as slowly as an narcoleptic sloth or beat Sonic the hedgehod to it.\n\nThe last point is nor good nor bad
column19: it's actually something any off roader knows : there are no roads (that I've seen) on this planet so do not build a low hanging vehicule as the slightest slope will probably damage the vehicule. So unless you manually build roads leading to New Rome you will always travel in bugies !"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game definitely has potential, in addition to being fun to play in it's current state. The devs are pretty transparent with their goals and timeline.

There's certainly a few things that are lacking (am I the only one who thinks rotocopters should be able to strafe instead of just yaw?)

The crafting system (the replicator) works quite well, and the interface is pretty intuitive. There are a few querks with equipping items and where they show up in your inventory (personal opinion, certainly doesn't affect gameplay).

The iso creation system is, in my opinion, what really sets this apart from other sandboxes. Not only can you create your own things out of blocks, but you can create your own useable items - vehicles, weapons, objects. The interface is a little intimidating at first, and isn't the most intuitive or user friendly, but once you get the hang of it, you can do some pretty amazing things! I'd like to see more data displayed while in the iso creator, but we're in alpha, and there's lots of development to go.

Overall, it's a beautiful game with some very innovative ideas. I can't wait to see where it goes, and I'm having lots of fun playing it as is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game could use some work but aside from the occasional bugs and glitches, It's not that bad for an early access game. I mean HECK! I'd go ahead and say that this game is BRILLIANT for an early access game!

The single-player mode is fun but it does take a long time to get around so I recommend getting some supplies fast and building a vehicle if you want to explore.

The Co-Op is in a sense more fun than single player but is a little glitchier than the forementioned.

Honestly I had more fun just exploring and finding all the wierd aliens I could! My favourite landscape or biome would need to be the the canyon area but all the different landscapes combine well and feel quite natural; The creatures on the otherhand are by far my favourite aspect of the game!
The amount of animals is amazing, with the sizes ranging from the tiny Vulpes Haola to the the enormous Testudo Mariturtle.

The best ai would probably be the unnamed cliff lizard thing in the canyon biome, It took me Four hours to find just one and even the the ai got the best of me....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*This review is based off an older version, around .72 alpha build
First off. Let me start with performance.
I do not lag on this game on any settings and with my computer underclocked. And it still looks wonderful.
Let me restate that,.... Space Engineers(on any world older than a day), Minecraft(for most people), 7 days to die, + any other game you can think of that is voxel based..... Planet Explorers not only looks better, but handles better.
Nuff said.

Music/sound: needs more variety if they are still on the same tracks as the last version I played. But for what they do have, the music is refreshing and fits right in. It is not intrusive at all. Sound had wierd glitches here and there, but stuff that was actively getting fixed and nothing that really stood out.

animation/combat: I am clumping these two together for a reason,... they are closely tied for the trouble parts. Overall its pretty good, both the animation and the combat. But something about combat makes me feel more like I am aiming for hit boxes and not an actual entity. I do not like this in the slightest, so even tho I would like to be a melee combatant, I feel forced into ranged combat because of this.
*I believe theres been some changes to combat that may effect my opinion on this, I will change my review to reflect more recent versions as I play them*

Scenery: Yes, this one warrants its own section. The landscape of Planet Explorers is beautiful. And the variety of foliage(trees, grass, bushes, flowers) is beyond what any other game I have played has attempted

Creatures: Again, something that I might not have commented on in any other game... Planet Explorers creature deserve a mention. The variety and detail put into the creatures is astonishing. And they keep adding more! I did 3 'Main' playthroughs of the storymode for this game before the last version- and EVERY time there was more creatures that I hadnt seen before! Someone in their department is pumping them out, and I am loving it!

Story: The story is actually pretty good if you pay attension to what is going on(i.e. dont skip thru text)
The presentation certainly is not winning any awards, but as far as I am concerned, it doesn't have to. What is nice here is that in storymode(singleplayer), the story is not shoved down your throat. You are free to pursue the story, or do your own thing.

Survival Aspect: This is a survival game after all, and thats what most of us(or at least me) come to do. And I must say that on the version I played, I wasnt as impressed as I hoped. It felt like survival was optional, and that should never be the case in a survival game. I don't know if that makes any sense, but... not hardcore enough for me? maybe.
Good news is I heard there is an editor thing planned that from what details I heard, will definately be able to accomidate anything I feel is missing here.

Developers: This one is of special note. I have never before PE seen a head of development for a game interact with the community, on a near daily basis. Furthermore, in the time I spent observing and partaking in the forums I have not seen so much straightforwardness and honestly from developers. This is both commendable and heartwarming. I will not provide examples, as they stand on the forums for all to see.
Also, it is easy to tell these developers actually care about their game.

Summary: It's a great game and only getting better,... I couldn't recommend it more. If still in doubt, try out the demo. I insist! Do the storymode first... the other modes are farther behind and don't accurately represent what the dev's are trying to accomplish.

**Note: I will update this review as I play newer versions.... anything here will likely change for the better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planet Explorers is a 3D RPG adventure game where you can explore, gather, hunt, harvest, build, and do some questing. It's still in progress, but so far it's rather enjoyable, though I look forward to its further development. This game is fairly fun to play so far, though it could use some FPS optimization. The game has developed nicely thus far, however, and I expect and look forward to quite good things for this game.

It has three modes: Story Mode, where you do the main questline & sidequests, Adventure Mode, which plays differently, and allows you to build your own colony with NPCs, and finally, Build Mode, where you can build whatever you'd like, and you receive infinite resources.

Nonetheless, it's enjoyable so far, and I think many people will like this game.

Problem with the Linux client, in case your character instantly dies when entering the world, and instantly dies again after revive, put this in startup options (without the quotes):

LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 %command%"

It turns out there is no OpenCL hardware support for Mac and Linux Ubuntu(*)
date: which means really terrible performance unfortunately.\n\n(*) Apparently due to broken nvidia 331 proprietary driver. In order to fix this
recommended:
you might have some luck with this approach (in the order mentioned below):

- apt-get install nvidia-cuda-toolkit
- apt-get install ocl-icd-opencl-dev
- reboot
- revert to "legacy 304 proprietary driver" from nvidia
- reboot

Use at your own risk

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's always the impulse to compare it to certain other sandbox games... but I don't know how. Planet Explorers plays like an RPG, crafting game, exploration, adventure, even a 3D modelling program!

* It's like Elements: You start with initial resources like plants and minerals, and can craft new technologies & accessories.
* It's like an RPG: Beautiful open world, small & large enemies, Obtain missions by talking to NPC's, some of which can join your party and eventually your colony (city)! They will fight with you & you can equip them with weapons, armors, items, or just give them stuff to carry.
* It's a sandbox: make tools to help you dig out the world. Search for ore deposits using your 3D scanner then use them to construct just about anything! (not player-designed clothing)
* It's 3D modelling software: Construct swords, shields, guns, land/sea/air vehicles, or just decoration objects like stairs, utilities, household, really anything you can think of!
Custom models are inserted into the game like this: If you have the resources required to build it, they will automatically be removed from your inventory and the object will appear. You can interact with it or pick it up anytime that you are next to it. An 'approved' build that has been picked up may be reused until it is destroyed; once it's built, it's built.

I have spent over 10 hours on Story mode so far and I have only just built my first car. I have leather armor, sword & shield, bow & rifle. My 2 followers have Steel armor & swords; they 'tank' while I shoot. I have barely explored the south-central part of the island. There are videos of immense constructs and firepower, enemies and adventure. I have only barely begun, and I am very much addicted :).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This isn't a bad game. I just didn't find myself getting into it, or liking it. I want to like it, but it just didn't do it for me. I understand this is an alpha, but as it is, I cannot recommend it.

First off, it is pretty demanding, hardware-wise. I have a 1900x1200 monitor, and had to launch it at 1280x800 to run it at a playable framerate. It is an alpha, though, so I don't know if that counts.

Anyway, I found the combat klunky, and that combined with the fact that the story isn't exactly the most engrossing story ever weaved, ruined the story mode for me. Survival was fun for a few hours, but didn't grab me. You can create cool stuff in the mode where you have unlimited resources, but again, didn't grab me.

I don't want to write a bad review, but in it's state, there are much better Early Access games out there. Don't bother.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With gorgeous visuals, solid gameplay and an eerie, engrossing atmosphere, Planet explorers is an adventure I urge you to undertake!
The story mode is the best part of the game in my opinion which says a lot considering sandbox/open world games are usually more fun to just mess with in free play. The characters are believable and the whole world feels alive and detailed.
To be fair, there are a few issues in places but they're mostly minor. No game breakers so far!
I'd write more but I have to go see what lies out to the west, in the desert. And finish building that buggy. And take out three more of those monsters... and collect more mushrooms...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is still in alpha, and is basically broken as hell. Be prepared to spend time configuring for your machine, stopping to make sure you don't overheat, looking things up because quests are wonky, cursing the clunky menus...etc. You will be frustrated at times.

BUT despite it all this is frankly still the best gaming experience I've had in many years. There is so much new fresh fun potential here. Honestly I can't think of any game I played during the entire last console generation that I enjoyed as much as my past week with Planet Explorers. (Maybe Just Cause 2, but only after the horrible story was over.) Finishing my first long journey west with Rol, arriving at our destination at sunset...wow. This is freedom, a huge world with constant surprises, discoveries and delights, totally open problem-solving, building and exploration. I hope a lot of games go in this direction as system capablities increase. Very little hand-holding also, and I hope it stays that way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be honest I was starting to avoid these early access games like a virus, I mean where is the motivation to finnish a game, when you have already been paid for it, and even though Steam are pretty awesome, they just dont lay down any rules for actually finishing what they started, 10% of my library is early access and I know that 90% of them are going nowhere.

Planet explorers is another rip off of minecraft, but compared to other early access games it looks great, and the building is new and innovative, the controls (still a tiny bit glitchy) are nice and the world is massive, with loads of well designed alien animals and plenty of game modes.

I could go on and on, but I wont, at the end of the day for the price of about 20 euro (i think thats what i paid) its a bargain, dont expect next gen graphics (but they are suprisingly good for early access) and enjoy!

Early Access Review

Having played the free earlier alpha on their website I was certainly impressed enough to buy it to play the latest versions.  There are some changes such as the controls (now you can set your own keys to use), graphical changes and extra modes but the core game hasn't been tampered with which even at this early stage is more playable than some full releases.

A sci-fi RPG game with mining and crafting parts but it's not Minecraft so don't come into this thinking you'll be doing the same thing as you were in Minecraft.  For one thing the mining is a bit clumsier and slower.  The crafting side is more powerful but does have a bit of a learning curve to get to grips with in the creation mode where you'll be building vehicles and buildings blueprints.

Try the demo first before buying but if you give it a chance you'll probably be smitten.

Early Access Review

EDITED 7/26/2014
I love this game. I don't really know how to sum it all up without getting all gushy and stuff so I'm just going to list what I feel are the highlights or otherwise different from other crafting survival games.
1. day/night/weather
2. it's dark inside caves
3. wide variety of alien creatures
4. wide variety of alien plants

6. handhelp resource scanner

10. alien simians that throw rocks (or maybe poo) at you
11. alien hominoids that shoot wierd rifles at you.

13. UFO

First review:

Game seems straightforward enough. Recipes can be accessed in the replicator, you've got a handheld computer you can use to scan for...something, I dunno yet. Adventure mode has random missions you can take although all I've seen so far is resource gathering missions.
Nice. Can't wait till it's finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Walking Simulator 2014!

OK It's really a great game! But...

Story mode - You can't really stop and play in a different style (like they said you can build base and farm,etc). You need hours of walking missions to get the scripts for the base. When you finally get them you are across the map and your next walking mission will be much closer. So you will go and try it. But if you start it you can't really stop (follow missions) and you had to fight huge enemies with your basic equipment because the game DIDNT give you TIME to rest and enjoy the world.

Adventure - Awesome!
Multiplayer - Even more awesome! And It seems like will be even better.

So the game is great, the story mode is really annoying. Like a 20+ hours tutorials and after 10 hours you figure out you had nothing to kill big things...

OH and watch out for saving!! Well for me but the autosave option didnt working very well... :/ And you will need your save files for sure!:)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlanet explorers is amazing. It's the first game in awhile that gave me that feeling of actually having a new experience. The world they created is captivating and definitely compels me into exploration. reviewText:
Early Access Review

With gorgeous visuals, solid gameplay and an eerie, engrossing atmosphere, Planet explorers is an adventure I urge you to undertake!
The story mode is the best part of the game in my opinion which says a lot considering sandbox/open world games are usually more fun to just mess with in free play. The characters are believable and the whole world feels alive and detailed.
To be fair, there are a few issues in places but they're mostly minor. No game breakers so far!
I'd write more but I have to go see what lies out to the west, in the desert. And finish building that buggy. And take out three more of those monsters... and collect more mushrooms...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is still in alpha, and is basically broken as hell. Be prepared to spend time configuring for your machine, stopping to make sure you don't overheat, looking things up because quests are wonky, cursing the clunky menus...etc. You will be frustrated at times.

BUT despite it all this is frankly still the best gaming experience I've had in many years. There is so much new fresh fun potential here. Honestly I can't think of any game I played during the entire last console generation that I enjoyed as much as my past week with Planet Explorers. (Maybe Just Cause 2, but only after the horrible story was over.) Finishing my first long journey west with Rol, arriving at our destination at sunset...wow. This is freedom, a huge world with constant surprises, discoveries and delights, totally open problem-solving, building and exploration. I hope a lot of games go in this direction as system capablities increase. Very little hand-holding also, and I hope it stays that way.

I had made a review before, saying how good it was... it... really isn't very good at all.
Take it from me, this game... just sucks.
Controls are a NIGHTMARE.
I can't tell if I'm walking or jumping
What does that button do?
The devs say they have a story?
HAH!
Amazingly bad story.
Wherever it is.
The learning curve is insane. You start with a knife and IMMEDIATELY after you kill something they expect you to know freaking calculus.
Seriously, the.. thing creator.. is so horrendously difficult to use, that I stopped trying completely after about the second attempt.
The tutorials are insanely bad. They don't tell you anything.
Now for the good things
The workshop is there
Animations are pretty nice
It can be fun sometimes.


5/10 It just.. really isn't good in its current state.
If you're going to buy it, buy it on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-NOTE: This review is for a game in alpha!
Very unique game with tons of creative ideas, but as it is in alpha, these ideas lack a lot of flare, and are very underdeveloped. In fact, all the game's ideas (not to mention the whole game itself) is packed to the brim with bugs and errors. The story mode is something I consider awful. The voice acting for all NPC's and keystory characters is annoying, and really feels like something you'd find at a high school acting club. The missions are all tedious, and rarely go beyond the MMORPG tropes of kill X of Y" or "Collect X of Y". This is especially disheartening considering this is a singleplayer storyline

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was a waste of money.
I have liked the idea of this game for quite a long time.  The fact that its still not finished and that i cannot play on a LAN with my friend without an internet connection have made me change my review from a positive to a negative.  Im sick and tired, as a paying customer, to make sacrifices in the name of DRM.  I have a detached garage with no internet access that I use for LAN parties.  The trend is these days is to require internet access so that all players have a valid copy.  I understand the desire to get paid for hard work, however, this only punishes paying customers.  For example, Diablo 3 requires an internet connection for the offline single player campaign.  Horribly intrusive for the paying customer hoping to play on the go, but a hacked version was released on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ within hours of the release of the game that didn't require an active internet connection.  The pirates actually got MORE playability on this one.
I will not dig a 200 ft trench to install lan cable to my garage, nor will i try to get a stable wireless connection to transmit that far.  I will simply sulk, leave bad reviews and do better research before I buy a game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYes!!! It's Cheap only 24.99 and you get nice graphics and its multiplayer. reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start with I started playing this befor .55 alpha and it has come a long way and still has a way to go and remember this is STILL ALPHA at the time of this review.

Where to start first the devs have added 3 zones from the time I started playing and still have more to add with ea area having a feel that makes them stand out. I will warn you stay away from the story as there are buggy spots and this isnt finished and having to restart to get them to work when added lated makes you play through it all again  Learn the ropes of the game and just use the quests to start your self out with that. I have restarted too much but alpha is all ways like that so this is just to warn you not to burn your self out.

The build system or what can I fly/drive around or make today system gives this more than just I little jump on any game out there right now. The ISO's (look this up for player made creations and I hope steam workshop soon), has many built for you just to download and add to your game. It ranges from the flyer to ground tanks, fun for every one and new guns, swords, shields you name it, some one has thought up a way to add it in or if you ask they mite add what you want.  With the ISO's just a build file this can be shown or given to any one and you can say hey look what I made today, this = a comunity of builders that will keep this game alive for a long time.

Have to say a tryed muti player when it wasnt working in older builds and havent tryed it on newer builds so I wont say anything I have been told it runs better and most problems have been solved.  Alpha build is where you fix problems and they are fixing it, you will have to try this your self.

I keep coming back to this game and love its on steam now, so I know when a new build is up. I try new ideas explore and enjoy how this is as close to realism a vox game has come so far, well it still has lasers and cannons and space ships to new planets and .... yea not that real but still fun.
